snippet: Sony’s executives now say they knew that basing a film on the assassination of Kim Jong-un of North Korea had inherent risks.
abstract: Sony Pictures' decision to greenlight film The Interview, comedy that centers on assassination of North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, has led company into geopolitical mess; decision enraged Kim, and company became target of brutal cyberattack, with suspicion falling on North Korean cyberunit; leaked emails reveal unusual tension over film between Sony's executives in US and Japan, where North Korea looms as serious threat.

byline.original: By MARTIN FACKLER, BROOKS BARNES and DAVID E. SANGER
byline.contributor: Martin Fackler reported from Tokyo, Brooks Barnes from Los Angeles, and David E. Sanger from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Makiko Inoue and Hisako Ueno from Tokyo; Su-Hyun Lee and Choe Sang-Hun from Seoul, South Korea; Edward Wong from Beijing; and Michael Cieply from Los Angeles.

lead_paragraph: Sony’s executives now say they knew that basing a film on the assassination of Kim Jong-un of North Korea had inherent risks.

headline.main: Sony’s International Incident: Making Kim Jong-un’s Head Explode
headline.print_headline: Sony’s International Incident: Making Kim’s Head Explode
